Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2009 12:11PM shockedat39 wrote: I've been like that since right before my surgery.  I was originally so freaked about the surgery I couldn't even think past it to treatment.  But 2 or 3 days before the surgery a total calm came over me and I for the most part (other than a few "moments") I've been that way ever since. Just as an FYI, I had 4 lymph nodes and my tumor was 3cm.  With chemo, radiation and tamoxifen my oncologist told me 10%.  I don't know how much credence to give all of this "percentage of recurrence" but it seems like my oncologist would give you even better odds than that.  Do you want her number?  LOL.

Posts.Content: shockedat39 wrote: I'm wondering if this has happened to anyone else.  I'm almost a year (in April) out of chemo.  I am having the absolute worst time with allergies, which I have never had before.  It's gotten to the point where if I see a speck of dust flying in the air, I run the other way, lol.  Night time is terrible.  I'm very sure it's allergies, not a cold or anything else more sinister. I discussed with my onc and she said it happens sometimes after chemo due to low immune systems, etc.  I had a hard time last year but I figured it was because I had no nose hair, lmao. Anyway, I was wondering if this has happened to anyone else, how bad was it and how long does it last?  I'm making an appointment to see an allergy doctor so hopefully I can get some relief. Posts.Title: This makes me feel terrible...anyone else? shockedat39 chrishat

Posts.Content: shockedat39 wrote: I almost posted this in the "You know you have cancer when..." string but then I realized it's not funny.  In the almost two years since I've been diagnosed and treated for breast cancer about 6 or 7 of my friends have found scary lumps and bumps (including one of my friend's husband!).  In every case, because of my situation, these friends have confided in me, asked my advice, etc.  I'm always happy to hear it and give it.  In each case, thank goodness, it turned out to not be cancer.  In each case I have had to force myself to be cheerful and celebrate with these friends.  Don't get me wrong, I DO NOT wish this on anyone else and would be absolutely devastated for anyone with a positive result.  It's just that it makes me feel so alone.  Does that make sense? I'm hoping there is someone out there who feels the same way and this is not some awful dark side coming out of me. Dx 11/26/2008, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 2, 4/27 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: This makes me feel terrible...anyone else? shockedat39 chrishat

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2010 01:19PM shockedat39 wrote: I completely agree with all of you ladies.  There is nothing "sweet and girly" about breast cancer and I think the pink brigade poo-poos the real strength and courage of all of my sisters (and brothers) who have fought and/or continue to fight this monster.  And it especially ticks me off when it is such an obvious retail marketing ploy (can you just imagine the meetings at retail headquarters where they discuss getting ready for "Breast Cancer Awareness month?).  I think what did me in was the pink Snuggie I saw at the flipping Food Lion! Interestingly, I had a follow up appointment this morning (all is well, hooray!) at the Cancer Center and I walked in fully expecting the office to look like it's been hosed down in Pepto Bismol (Steel Magnolias, anyone?)  To my delighted surprise, I didn't see one pink ribbon anywhere!  Do you think maybe they get it? And if I may add to the rant...I'm almighty tired of hearing newsfolks say that so-and-so lost his/her battle with cancer.  You know what?  I had my boobs cut off, I went 8 rounds with chemo, 30 days of radiation, painful reconstruction.  I managed to work, take care of my family and keep things almost normal.   Now that it's over, we have gone back to life as we knew it and everyone is pretty darn happy.  Even if this comes back and gets me a month, a year or 10 years from now, I've won.
Posts.Title: My pink problem Melinda41 daffodil45

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2011 12:32AM shockedat39 wrote: My girls were much younger than your children (4 and 9) so I'm not sure my advice would be of any use to you but I did want to share a story that might make you smile.  I was diagnosed right after Thanksgiving and my BMX was already scheduled for December 23rd.  We told the girls that I had something in me that could make me sick and that the doctors were going to take it out.  I would be in the hospital but I would come home on Christmas Eve.  The older one was a bit concerned but the 4-year old just said "Oh....is Santa still coming?"  It made me laugh and right then I had a weird feeling everything was going to be ok...

Posts.Title: suicide ideation lovemyfamilysomuch Texas357

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2009 09:30AM shockedat39 wrote: Hi Jancie, I'm so pleased that your bone scans came out clean.  For me, the "did it spread?" scans were the worst.  I had them over the holidays and had to wait...god awful...and thank goodness I got good news like you. I'm sorry you are confused about what you are going to do and I hate that the mastectomy pictures are contributing to it.  I never really looked at them because I was afraid of the same thing.  I will say this; I wouldn't change my decision to have bi-lateral with expanders BUT I wish I had given myself more time to process it.  I basically made my decision by the time I got home from the Drs. office and didn't think much about it again (I'm being a bit cavalier but I think you get the idea).  I'm not much of a "My Body, My Self" type of person and didn't see much point in mourning the girls.  Now I wish I had.  I think it's awesome that you are giving yourself all kinds of time to process this and be sure you are 100% comfortable with how you will be handling it. One final note, the morning after surgery my PS came in and freaked me out by saying it was time to pull off the bandages.  Of course I had 15 pamphlets telling me that I should do that privately in front of the mirror or whatever so I was thrown off, LOL.  However, you can't beat starting your recovery by hearing your husband say "That's not bad, hon, and they're going to look awesome when he's done." :) Just for that I think we'll stay married! Best of luck, honey. Diane

Posts.Title: Concerned, Confused, and Angry LesleyZ LesleyZ

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2011 02:49PM shockedat39 wrote: Hi Lesley, That's positive that your doctor thinks the nodes are not involved.  I don't blame you for being ticked off at your other doctors, especially in light of the fact that your current one can identify the cancer from your u/s and mammo.  You're right to focus on your treatment but I wouldn't blame you if you pursued litigation in the future.  To your question about going back to work after bi-lateral mast., at the time I was working from home as a contractor.   This sounds crazy now, but I was back working in less than a week.  But I did work from home.  And I was a contractor so there was no disability or family leave.  It was work or don't get paid.  I was actually able to function pretty well.  I didn't have a lot of pain and was off the heavy pain-killers in about 3 days and down to just a lot of Advil.  I know everyone has different experiences/pain thresholds, etc. but if you really need to get back to work within a couple weeks I'll bet you could figure out a way to do it (work from home, get rides, go back part time). I hope this information was remotely helpful to you.  Feel free to PM me if you have any questions. Best wishes, Diane

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2009 11:24AM shockedat39 wrote: Hi everyone, Well, today is exactly a month since I originally posted this thread.  Since then I have had a bi-lateral mast with expanders.  To my absolute delight, I had very little pain, was up and around within a few days of surgery and I'm able, just a few short weeks later, to hug my little girls (yes, I can do laundry and whatnot also but the hugging is what I missed most of all). My path report was pretty encouraging also.  We knew there was lymph node involvement prior to surgery but the report showed 4 out 27 positive.  Me likey those odds. I also had my first round of chemo this past Friday.  Yesterday was not fabulous (it felt like a hangover and who didn't nurse of few or more of those in college?)  but today I'm feeling pretty good.  I understand it will get worse, but maybe if it just gets a little worse every time it won't be so bad.  And think of how great I'll feel when it's all over!!! With all of the treatment we are throwing at this my chance of recurrence becomes 10%!  How can I frown at that? I am more convinced than ever that I am a healthy woman who is doing everything I can to stay that way. That said, I am so thrilled that this thread took off like it did.  I have enjoyed each and every post, regardless if the opinion was similar or different to mine.  You are all incredible women coping the best way for you. Diane

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2009 03:57PM shockedat39 wrote: Jess - jrgolomb - I just wanted to sare something with you re: rads and tissue expanders, assuming the plan is for you to still have rads.  It turns out I will only be getting 28 rounds.  They will NOT be doing the boost.  I probably won't explain it very well but basically, the boost is intended to treat the mastectomy scar area and once the expander is in it moves the scar so far away from the tissue and chest wall that doing a boost doesn't do anything except expose us to more radiation unnecessarily and cause issues with the TE.  He said that not doing the boost would be better cosmetically for the TE reconstruction in general.  When I told my onc I'd gladly compromise my TE rather than have even minor risk that it comes back he told me there was no greater risk at all.  Anyway, I just wanted to pass that on to you. :)  Hope everyone is having a great day! Diane

Posts.Content: May 1, 2009 02:22PM shockedat39 wrote: Hey there Jewels, So I met with my radiation oncologist yesterday.  Turns out my fake tatas are too large for them to be able to get to the spots they need to get to (I'm not having radiation on the left one but it is "in the way") so I have to have the SOBs DRAINED!!!!  I'm not sure how much yet.  The good news is, the skin and muscle is stretched enough that I probably won't have to have them refilled.  That is also the bad news as I will now have floppy tits through the majority of the summer! To add to the fun, I was supposed to have my port taken out today.  Here's where the robo-rack strikes again as it is directly under the port so they would have to make an additional incision way up high so as not to poke a hold in the tissue expander.  Guess what?  It didn't come out.  I'm waiting for the deflation. I'm frustrated beyond belief but thinking that maybe God has decided that this is only set back I'll have and then I'm done.  Forever :)

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2009 01:33PM shockedat39 wrote: Count me in with the weight-gainers.  Oh boy, anyone who thought I was going to be chemo-Sally, all emaciated and whatnot will surely be surprised.  I've gained 6 pounds!  The onc nurse thinks it all has to do with them basically forcing me into menopause (along with my fun new sleep patterns) but I blame the wonderful meals we are getting from our dear friends and neighbors.  We have had so many fantastic pasta dishes over the last two months!  And I can't get enough of it.  They don't call it comfort food for nothing!  I've started walking on the treadmill some so hopefully that will prevent any further gain. The last few days have been very tough emotionally, mostly because I'm tired as hell.  While I'm thrilled that A/C is over I feel like I still have so much more ahead of me (Taxol/radition/port removal/implant exchange/gah!).  Also, I haven't mentioned it much but I'm still working about 35 hours per week.  I'm extremely lucky that I work from home and I'm a contractor so I have a bit of flexibility.  That said, the bills still have to be paid so I don't have much of a choice.  It's overwhelming sometimes! Like clockwork, every Wednesday or so after treatment the recurrence thoughts start creeping up, too (what if this is all for nothing? what if chemo is over and it comes right back? how would I ever do this again?).  I think it must be the culmination of everything.  I could almost set my watch by it!  I will need therapy desparately when this is all over.  Half the battle is admitting it, right?  LOL Wow, did this end up being a long post!!!  Thanks, as always for listening. I hope everyone else is feeling ok and having a good day! Diane

Posts.Content: May 19, 2009 08:20AM shockedat39 wrote: I have to chime in on the eyebrow/eyelash thing as well.  It's annoying that now that I'm done with chemo it's so, so obvious that I've had it.  Those suckers hung on until almost my last treatment!!!  Thank goodness Frink (that's the name my dd gave my wig, lol) has bangs.  I just wear sunglasses as much as I can.  I have absolutely NO talent for drawing the eyebrows in, they just look worse when I try. Went to support group with my 9-year old last night.  It has been awesome for her, for me, not so much.  The group is really supposed to be for the kids but the adults split up and have their own meeting.  I swear I never think I'm going to die from this until I go to this support group.  The group is comprised of men and women with all types of cancer in all stages.  One lady (whom I'd only met once) died a few weeks ago.  Last night a few of them spent 45 minutes talking about making memories for the children after they're gone.  Gah!  One gentleman, who is obviously very bad off, went on about how his 4 year old isn't going to remember him, he'll just be a faded photograph etc.  I walked out of there shaking. Thank goodness it's breaking for the summer.  DD really loves it...last night they did a tour through the chemo rooms, radition, etc.  It's been great for her.  I just don't think I can stomach the "adult time" anymore.  I suppose I could drop her off but I would feel tacky doing that. Wow, this turned into a rant.  It's nice to have a place where I can say all of this without fear of anger or misunderstanding. Everyone feel good and be well today. Diane
Posts.Title: Starting chemo January 2009? lisalisa ktym

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2009 12:40PM shockedat39 wrote: Hi Jewels, I hope everyone is feeling good/ok/not like crap today! Holtbolt, I totally hear you about your onc visit.  While she doesn't volunteer negative comments, my onc is not much of a cheerleader either.  And I agree, I think we all need that.  Maybe they are just covering themselves so we can't go back to them later and say "you said I did great."  That would get me down too.  It will be interesting to see what my dr. does when I go back for my first follow up. I've been reading all the comments re: wigs and hats and I have to say I have a completely different perspective on the whole matter.  I don't wear a wig to make others comfortable.  I wear it to make myself comfortable.  I just don't feel like me without hair and knew I would wear a wig from the get go (I even threatened to sleep in it for a while.  That never happened, lol).  I've been extremely open about my situation and there is no one that knows me that doesn't know I've had chemo and am wearing a wig so I'm not trying to hide anything by wearing it.  I've never like to draw a lot of attention to myself and that's what I feel like going out bald or in a scarf would do.  With summer coming I know I'm going to figure out what I'm going to do as the SOB will be very hot on my head.  Anyway, just thought I'd add my perspective to the discussion! All of that said, my hair is starting to grow back with a vengeance!  It started about halfway through Taxol and now it's long enough to be laying down when I take my wig off (does that make any sense?).  I can't wait to see how it takes off when all of the Taxol is actually out of my body!  Maybe the Mane and Tail really does work!  I wonder if they make it for eyebrows! Everyone be well and have a great day! Diane

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2009 08:02PM shockedat39 wrote: For me, the raw fear of recurrence has subsided.  It's not that I never think about it but I find I can go for days vs. hours without really thinking about it.  Every time the fear does creep up I ask myself  "Ok, so say it does come back in 2 years, 5 years, 10 years, etc.  Do I want to regret living in fear for 10 years or be able look back and say it was a great 10 years?"  It probably sounds stupid (especially because it's hard to put that in writing...LOL)  But it really works for me.  Puts things in perspective. And to be honest, I don't see anything wrong with living in la la land when it comes to recurrence.  Why not tell myself it won't happen?  I've thrown everything I can at this sumbitch so why not believe I got rid of it completely? PureE, I love your response to your obgyn.  I get slightly irritated when people refer to me as "having cancer".  I also tell them I no longer have it.  Cancer is SO last year...lol. You're all amazing. Diane

Posts.Content: shockedat39 wrote: ....that a lump the size of a golf ball could possibly not show up on a mammogram?  I feel like such an idiot for not having known that and I'm so mad at myself because if I had known that I might have had things re-checked earlier.  I went for my baseline in May and had a gyn exam in July.  All clear.  The lump came slowly to light as I lost weight (intentionally) over the last 3 months.  It's just so big now that I can't believe even 39 year old dense breast tissue could hide it.  But it does.  In fact, when I went for diagnostics the radiologist almost sent me on my way because the mammogram was once again clear.  Only a follow up ultrasound showed a real problem. Part of me feels like this is some big secret I didn't know.  Part of me thinks maybe somebody told me along the line and I just didn't listen/hear it.  I'm only praying that my ignorance hasn't made things worse than they already are. :( Dx 11/26/2008, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 2, 4/27 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Am I the Only One Who Didn't Know???? shockedat39 whoopsiedoodles

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2010 02:36PM shockedat39 wrote: It's tricky.  I had expanders put in when I had my mx.  I got them expanded throughout chemo and then had to have them "deflated" for radiation because they were in the way.  Not completely deflated, but a lot.  My PS was pissed and thought the rad oncologist could have worked around it, lol. For the record, I have a C cup but, as you know, they have to go a bit larger on the expanders. I had minimum discomfort with the pre-rads expansions but the ones after were awful because the skin was so much tighter.  Maybe that's why your PS is going to take skin from your back? Anyway, I don't know if there's any great way to do it.  As much as having the expanders deflated sucked, I'm glad I didn't have to have an additional surgery to have them put in. Good luck!
